ygData.subject: Re: Voodoo3 2000
ygData.msgSnippet: STB and 3DFX are one and the same now. 3DFX bought up STB and now all cards from 3DFX will only have the 3DFX logo on them. No more Diamond Multimedia,
ygData.messageBody:
STB and 3DFX are one and the same now. 3DFX bought up STB and now all cards
from 3DFX will only have the 3DFX logo on them. No more Diamond Multimedia,
Creative Labs, etc versions.

----- Original Message -----
From: Nick <brutalny@...>
To: <EverQuest@onelist.com>
Sent: Wednesday, June 02, 1999 7:02 AM
Subject: Re: [EverQuest] Voodoo3 2000


> From: "Nick" <brutalny@...>
>
> I got a voodoo3 2000 pci (i have an old k6-2 300 mhz so no agp slots) for
> the one reason that all the other 3d cards out there need agp slots. It
has
> worked great the speed is excellent, I've had no problems and i think you
> should get one. if you do get one don't get the stb one, it is just a
cheap
> version of the 3dfx one. make sure it is a 3dfx voodoo3, stb uses 3dfx
> chips on cheap boards. i used to have a tnt and voodoo3 blows it out of
the
> water, not to mention voodoo3 is so much easier to use and install that
tnt2
> is not even worth the purchase. at least until about 2 years, but by then
> i'm sure 3dfx will have another 32 bit card out.
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: <EverQuest@onelist.com>
> To: <EverQuest@onelist.com>

> > Message: 6
> > Date: Tue, 01 Jun 1999 11:32:40 -0500
> > From: blizzard15@...
> > Subject: Voodoo3 2000, System, Cable Modem
> >
> > I am building a new computer and I was wondering if any of you have had
> any
> > experience with the Voodoo3 2000. Does it give good enough performance
to
> > warrant buying it? Also would the following system give good performance
> on
> > EverQuest?
> >
> > Celeron 433
> > 128 MB PC100 SDRAM
> > Diamond Monster MX300
> > Abit BX6 Rev2
> > Maxtor 10.2GB 5400 RPM
> > Diamond SupraExress 56K Internal ISA
> >
> > Also I've been seeing that the Cable Modems aren't that good for EQ, but
I
> > was wondering how bad are they? Will they get at least better
performance
> > than a 56K? Answers to any of these questions would be very appreciated.
> >
> > -Blizzard
> >
> >
> >
> >
>
____________________________________________________________________________
> ___
> >
>
____________________________________________________________________________
> ___
> >
> > Message: 7
> > Date: 01 Jun 1999 12:51:36 -0400
> > From: Chris_Mattos@...
> > Subject: Re: Voodoo3 2000, System, Cable Modem
> >
> > A cable modem will do nothing to lower packetloss. What it will do is
> decrease ping time, which can lessen the impact of packetloss problems.
The
> only way to (hopefully) lessen packetloss problems is to try a different
ISP
> (which, subscribing to a cable modem service, you will accomplish). The
> main problem with cable modems, however, is that as more people in your
area
> subscribe to cable modem service, your connection quality will decrease.
> This is also true for dial up service, but to a far lesser extent since
they
> are low connection speed to begin with. As I will explain in a moment,
this
> is not as a real big problem. DSL, supposedly, does not have this
downfall.
> >
> > There were recent reports that the @Home service was experiencing all
> kinds of problems, including bad connections to the EQ servers. Not being
a
> cable modem subscriber, I do not know how true these reports are.
> >
> > The final thing to consider is that EQ is designed to work with clients
> using standard dial-up service. Dial-up customers are in the vast
majority
> so Sony/Verant, of course, are going to cater to them primarily. What
this
> means is a higher connection speed to the EQ servers will not gain you an
> unrealistic advantage since the EQ servers are not designed to take full
> advantage of high speed connections. What you will gain is a more
reliable
> connection (no hang-ups) and better ping (which, as mentioned above, can
> help lessen the impact of high packetloss). It will, of course, be a
faster
> connection to the EQ servers, just not as big a difference in speed as you
> would see surfing the web.
> >
> > As for the Voodoo3 card, I don't really know for sure. Connection speed
> is the bottleneck, so anything Voodoo2/TNT or better will be fine.
Voodoo3
> will probably be better than VooDoo2 (in EQ), but probably not as big a
> difference as going from Voodoo1 to Voodoo2. I run a VooDoo Banshee and I
> work fine.
> >
> > The rest of your system kicks, so I wouldn't worry about it much.
> >
> > Chris
> >
> >
> >

> > Message: 13
> > Date: Tue, 1 Jun 1999 14:56:30 -0500
> > From: "Daniel P. Sniderman" <slide@...>
> > Subject: Re: Voodoo3 2000, System, Cable Modem
> >
> > While I have to accept Trevor's observation on QC from STB - I have a V3
> > 2000 and its behaved flawlessly..
> >
> > I have a couple of comments to make:
> >
> > 1) From most research I've seen - the TnT2 Ultra is a greater performer
> than
> > the Vooodoo3 2000 - especially given the speeds they are clocked at.
The
> > TnT2 also will support 32-bit textures - which will make a HUGE
difference
> > that the 16-bit hardware that the Voodoo3 (22-bit in software but that
> will
> > cause another performance hit) Note that the 2000 is easily
overclockable
> > (but you'll need to add a fan). Note that as far as I know - there's
not
> a
> > single game out there now that supports above 16-bit textures so TODAY
> this
> > isn't an issue.
> >
> > On-the-other-hand:
> > The 2000 cost me $129 at Best Buy - the TnT2 Ultra will cost AT LEAST
$100
> > more than that (possibly more - I haven't been pricing them)
> > If you are on a budget this is huge. Also keep in mind - if you are
ONLY
> > playing Everquest - I've seen TONS of posts from people having problems
> with
> > the V770. Sounds like Diamond (Nvidia?) need to fix the driver for EQ.
My
> > 2000 has behaved flawlessly.
> >
> > Also - the Matrox G400 is out now as well a buddy of mine claims it
smokes
> > the TnT2 - but I haven't done research to verify this. If you can
afford
> > $250 list for a V770 Ultra or a Matrox G400 AND plan on playing games
> other
> > than EQ consider forgoing the V3 2000
> >
> > In my opinion - the 2000 is the best performer for the price (also - I
am
> > running a 300 MHz machine so I won't see a speed difference with the
> faster
> > cards anyway). But given Trevor's concern - save that receipt, packing
> > materials, etc in case you have to return a defective card. I haven't
had
> > ANY probs with the 2000 and am REALLY satisfied with it.
> >
> > 2) SOME I repeat SOME people how are on @Home cable modem service have
> > severely high Packet Loss problems with Everquest. MANY people on the
> same
> > company have no problems at all. If you are considering @home I would
> > recommend posting on alt.games.Everquest and the www.eqvault.com Tech
> > webboard asking for people in your exact area if they have problems. If
> > your cable is a different company I would sign up for cable as fast as
you
> > possibly can!
> >
> > Danny Sniderman
> >
> > ----- Original Message -----
> > From: Trevor Gray <xenogear@...>
> > To: <EverQuest@onelist.com>
> > Sent: Tuesday, June 01, 1999 12:59 PM
> > Subject: Re: [EverQuest] Voodoo3 2000, System, Cable Modem
> >
> >

> > deal.
> > >
> > > Trevor

> > Message: 16
> > Date: Wed, 2 Jun 1999 11:41:31 +1000
> > From: Michael_Wyatt@...
> > Subject: Re: Changing Resolution
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > F10.
> >
> > Higher res is only of use when you are in either full screen or full
> screen
> > with boxes, all the screens that have borders stay at 640x480 instead of
> > becoming
> > larger.
> >
> > Note that if you are using 1024x768 in full screen with boxes and you
hit
> > "i" to go
> > into your inventory then it will either switch to 640x480 ( irritating )
> or
> > change to
> > a 640x480 blot in the middle of the 1024x768 display, depending on
whether
> > you
> > have the "same resolution" option set in the display preferences.
> >
> >
> >
> >
